text: Transcriptional control of steroid - regulated apoptosis in murine thymoma cells .

Early studies in murine T cell lines indicated that transcriptional transactivation functions encoded in the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) N-terminal domain are required for glucocorticoid - mediated apoptosis .

However , more recent studies in human T cell lines have suggested that the N-terminal domain is not necessary for steroid - regulated apoptosis and that <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated transrepression may be the more critical mechanism .

To better understand the contribution of the <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> N-terminal transactivation domain in mediating murine thymocyte apoptosis , we stably transfected <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> variants , and the <extra_id_0> androgen receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> AR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) into receptor - negative S49 murine thymoma cells .

text: <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression levels were shown to be rate - limiting for initiating the apoptotic pathway , and a positive correlation between steroid sensitivity and <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated induction of an integrated mouse mammary tumor virus ( MMTV ) LTR reporter gene was observed .

Analysis of <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> chimeric receptors containing the potent <extra_id_0> VP16 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> E1A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> viral transactivation domains in place of the <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> N terminus revealed that even low level expression of these receptors resulted in both enhanced steroid sensitivity and MMTV induction , thus supporting a role for transactivation in apoptosis .

In contrast , we found that <extra_id_0> AR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can initiate apoptosis in S49 cells after treatment with 5 alpha-dihydrotestosterone , despite its relative inability to induce high level expression of MMTV .
To investigate this further , we examined the steroid - regulated expression of an endogenous thymocyte - specific gene called <extra_id_0> GIG18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

We found that <extra_id_0> GIG18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was rapidly induced to comparable levels by both <extra_id_0> AR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , demonstrating that <extra_id_0> AR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can indeed function as a transcriptional activator in S49 cells and , moreover , that <extra_id_0> GIG18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction may be a marker of early apoptotic events in steroid - treated cells .

text: Taken together , these results support our conclusion that transcriptional transactivation is a necessary signaling component of S49 cell apoptosis , although an additional role for <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated transrepression can not be excluded .
